coredata.dc:title: Chapter Nine The Role of the Sustainable Development Goals to Reduce the Global Burden of Malnutrition
coredata.prism:publicationName: Advances in Food Security and Sustainability
coredata.prism:copyright: Copyright © 2018 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
coredata.dc:creator: Sabbahi, Minna
Li, Jiewen
Davis, Claire
Downs, Shauna M.
coredata.dc:description: UNICEF's conceptual framework outlines the basic, underlying, and immediate causes of malnutrition and provides an overview of both the direct and indirect pathways to reduce malnutrition and improve health outcomes. Sustainable development goal (SDG) 2 aims to “end hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture”, which has the potential to directly influence nutrition outcomes. However, many of the other SDGs have the potential to improve nutrition outcomes through more indirect pathways. Using the UNICEF conceptual framework to guide our analysis, we examined the ways in which different SDGs could influence nutrition and health outcomes, and the pathways by which this could occur. However, large data gaps exist making it difficult to accurately assess the current state of SDGs in many countries and regions. In order to increase accountability for the SDGs, the existing gaps in data collection must be addressed. This will enable countries to examine both the indirect and the direct pathways to improving nutrition outcomes globally.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Malnutrition
Sustainable development goals
Nutrition policy

xocs:item-toc-entry.xocs:item-toc-section-title: The Current State of SDG Indicators Across Countries and Regions
Maternal and Child Malnutrition: Short- and Long-Term Consequences
Indicators of Underlying Causes of Child and Maternal Malnutrition
Indicators of Basic Causes of Maternal and Child Undernutrition

ce:figure.ce:label: Fig. 1

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: UNICEF conceptual framework of the determinants of child undernutrition.

ce:figure.ce:source: Source: United Nations Children's Fund, 2015. UNICEF's approach to scaling up nutrition for mothers and their children. Discussion paper. Programme Division, UNICEF, New York, June, https://www.unicef.org/nutrition/files/Unicef_Nutrition_Strategy.pdf.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: The ways in which the Sustainable Development Goals can influence the basic, underlying, and immediate causes of maternal and child undernutrition based on the UNICEF framework.
The Pathways by Which SDGs Can Improve Malnutrition

row.entry: Goal 1: End poverty in all its forms everywhere
1.1 By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 per day

Reduced poverty → increased financial and physical capital → improved food security, feeding practice, household environment, and access to health services → more adequate dietary intake and reduced risk for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of population below the international poverty line, by sex, age, employment status, and geographical location (urban/rural)
1.2 By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women, and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions
a. Proportion of population living below the national poverty line by sex and age
b. Proportion of men, women, and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions
1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable

Increased social protection and extended coverage → improved social and physical capital → improved food security, feeding practice, household environment, and access to health services → more adequate dietary intake and reduced risk for disease → reduced undernutrition

a. Proportion of population covered by social protection floors/systems, by sex, distinguishing children, unemployed persons, older persons, persons with disabilities, pregnant women, newborns, work injury victims, and the poor and the vulnerable

1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership, and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology, and financial services, including microfinance

Equal rights and increased access to resources → improved financial, physical, and social capital → improved food security, feeding practice, household environment, and access to health services → more adequate dietary intake and reduced risk for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of population living in households with access to basic services
b. Proportion of total adult population with secure tenure rights to land, with legally recognized documentation and who perceive their rights to land as secure by sex and by type of tenure

1.a Ensure significant mobilization of resources from a variety of sources, including through enhanced development cooperation, in order to provide adequate and predictable means for developing countries, in particular least developed countries, to implement programs and policies to end poverty in all its dimensions

Increased resource mobilization → increased and improved program implementation and policies to reduce poverty → improved social, financial, human, and physical capital → improved food security, feeding practice, household environment, and access to health services → more adequate dietary intake and reduced risk for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of resources allocated by the government directly to poverty reduction programs
b. Proportion of total government spending on essential services (education, health, and social protection)

1.b Create sound policy frameworks at the national, regional, and international levels, based on propoor and gender-sensitive development strategies, to support accelerated investment in poverty eradication actions

Sound policy frameworks → improved political and social capital → improved food security, feeding practice, household environment, and access to health services → more adequate dietary intake and reduced risk for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of government recurrent and capital spending to sectors that disproportionately benefit women, the poor, and vulnerable groups
Goal 2: End hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture
2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious, and sufficient food all year round
Increased access to food → increased household food security and improved feeding practices → improved dietary intake and reduced risks for diseases → reduced undernutrition
b. Prevalence of moderate or severe food insecurity in the population, based on the Food Insecurity Experience Scale (FIES)

2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant, and lactating women and older persons

Improved nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant, and lactating women → increased productivity → increased financial, physical, and social capital → increased household food security, feeding practice, household environment, and improved feeding practices → improved dietary intake and reduced risks for diseases → reduced undernutrition or intergeneration malnutrition in offspring
a. Prevalence of stunting (height for age <−2 standard deviation from the median of the World Health Organization (WHO) Child Growth Standards) among children under 5 years of age

b. Prevalence of malnutrition (weight for height >+2 or <−2 standard deviation from the median of the World Health Organization (WHO) Child Growth Standards) among children under 5 years of age by type (wasting and overweight)

2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists, and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets, and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment

Increased agricultural productivity → increased financial and physical capital → improved food security, feeding practice, household environment, and access to health services → more adequate dietary intake and reduced risk for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Volume of production per labor unit by classes of farming/pastoral/forestry enterprise size
b. Average income of small-scale food producers by sex and indigenous status

2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding, and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality

A more sustainable food production system → more stable and continuous food availability → increased food security → more adequate dietary intake and reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of agricultural area under productive and sustainable agriculture

2.a Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development, and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries
Increased investment in agriculture sector → increased agriculture productivity → enhanced food security → more adequate dietary intake and reduced risk for diseases → reduced undernutrition
a. The agriculture orientation index for government expenditures
b. Total official flows (official development assistance plus other official flows) to the agriculture sector

2.b Correct and prevent trade restrictions and distortions in world agricultural markets, including through the parallel elimination of all forms of agricultural export subsidies and all export measures with equivalent effect, in accordance with the mandate of the Doha Development Round

Improved world agricultural markets regulation → more stable economic context → increased financial, human, physical, and social capital → improved food security, care, and feeding practices and household environments → more adequate dietary intake and reduced risk for disease → reduced undernutrition

2.c Adopt measures to ensure the proper functioning of food commodity markets and their derivatives and facilitate timely access to market information, including on food reserves, in order to help limit extreme food price volatility

Limited extreme food price volatility → more stable food price → more stable financial capital and ability to purchase food → improved food security, household environment, and access to health services → more adequate dietary intake and reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Indicator of food price anomalies
Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3.1 By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births

Reduced maternal mortality → improved care and feeding practices for newborns → more adequate dietary intake and reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition in offspring
Reduced maternal mortality → more and longer work opportunity → increased income → improved food security and household environment → more adequate dietary intake and reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
b. Proportion of births attended by skilled health personnel

3.2 By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1000 live births
3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria, and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases, and other communicable diseases
Reduced disease incidence and prevalence → increased absorption of nutrients → reduced undernutrition
a. Number of new HIV infections per 1000 uninfected population by sex, age, and key populations
d. Hepatitis B infections per 100,000 population
e. Number of people requiring interventions against neglected tropical diseases
3.4 By 2030, reduce by one-third premature mortality from noncommunicable diseases through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being
Improved mental health → improved nutrition and dietary intake → reduced risk of noncommunicable diseases
a. Mortality rate attributed to cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes, or chronic respiratory disease

3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive healthcare services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programs
Increased access to and coverage for healthcare services → better pregnancy outcome and reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of women of reproductive age (aged 15–49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods.
b. Adolescent birth rate (aged 10–14 years; aged 15–19 years) per 1000 women in that age group

3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential healthcare services and access to safe, effective, quality, and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all

More education on reproductive health → increased birth spacing → improved household environment, feeding practices, and food security → more adequate dietary intake and reduced risk for disease → reduced undernutrition
Increased knowledge on family planning → reduced adolescent birth rate → more nutrition needs met during adolescence → better future pregnancy outcomes such as increased food security and improved household environment → reduced undernutrition

a. Coverage of essential health services (defined as the average coverage of essential services based on tracer interventions that include reproductive, maternal, newborn and child health, infectious diseases, noncommunicable diseases and service capacity and access, among the general and the most disadvantaged population)
b. Number of people covered by health insurance or a public health system per 1000 population
3.9 By 2030, substantially reduced the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water, and soil pollution and contamination
Reduced pollutions from hazardous chemicals, air, and water → improved household environment and care and feeding practices → reduced risk for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution
b. Mortality rate attributed to unsafe water, unsafe sanitation, and lack of hygiene (exposure to unsafe Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene for All (WASH) services)

3.b Support the research and development of vaccines and medicines for the communicable and noncommunicable diseases that primarily affect developing countries, provide access to affordable essential medicines and vaccines, in accordance with the Doha Declaration on the TRIPS Agreement and Public Health, which affirms the right of developing countries to use to the full the provisions in the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights regarding flexibilities to protect public health, and, in particular, provide access to medicines for all
Increased access to vaccines and medication → better pregnancy outcome and newborn health → reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition

a. Proportion of the population with access to affordable medicines and vaccines on a sustainable basis
b. Total net official development assistance to medical research and basic health sectors

3.c Substantially increase health financing and the recruitment, development, training, and retention of the health workforce in developing countries, especially in least developed countries and small island developing states

Increased quantity and quality of health workforce → increased access to health services and improved care practices → reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
Increased quantity of health workforce → increased employment opportunity and increased financial capital → improved food security and household environments → more adequate dietary intake and risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Health worker density and distribution
3.d Strengthen the capacity of all countries, in particular developing countries, for early warning, risk reduction, and management of national and global health risks
Improved health system management → improved quality and access to health services → improved disease management and reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. International Health Regulations (IHR) capacity and health emergency preparedness
Goal 4: Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes

More access to quality education → increased employment opportunity, increased income and literacy → improved care and feeding practices, food security, and household environments → improved diet and reduced disease → reduced undernutrition for themselves and offspring

a. Proportion of children and young people: (a) in grades 2/3, (b) at the end of primary, and (c) at the end of lower secondary achieving at least a minimum proficiency level in (i) reading and (ii) mathematics by sex
4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and preprimary education so that they are ready for primary education
a. Proportion of children under 5 years of age who are developmentally on track in health, learning, and psychosocial well-being by sex
b. Participation rate in organized learning (1 year before the official primary entry age) by sex
4.3 By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational, and tertiary education, including university
a. Participation rate of youths and adults in formal and nonformal education and training in the previous 12 months by sex
4.4 By 2030, substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs, and entrepreneurship

Improved skills → increased employment opportunity and income → improved household financial capital → improved food security and access to health services → improved diet and reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of youth and adults with information and communications technology (ICT) skills by type of skill

4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access to all levels of education and vocational training for the vulnerable, including persons with disabilities, indigenous peoples, and children in vulnerable situations

More access to quality education → increased employment opportunity and increased income → improved care and feeding practices, food security, and household environments → improved diet and reduced disease → reduced undernutrition for themselves and offspring

a. Parity indices (female/male, rural/urban, bottom/top wealth quintile, and others such as disability status, indigenous peoples, and conflict-affected, as data become available) for all education indicators on this list that can be disaggregated
4.6 By 2030, ensure that all youth and a substantial proportion of adults, both men and women, achieve literacy and numeracy
a. Percentage of population in a given age group achieving at least a fixed level of proficiency in functional (a) literacy and (b) numeracy skills by sex
4.a Build and upgrade education facilities that are child, disability and gender sensitive and provide safe, nonviolent, inclusive, and effective learning environments for all

Improved education facility infrastructure → improved school attendance → increased employment opportunity, income, and literacy → improved care and feeding practices, food security, and household environments → improved diet and reduced disease → reduced undernutrition for themselves and offspring

a. Proportion of schools with access to (a) electricity, (b) the Internet for pedagogical purposes, (c) computers for pedagogical purposes, (d) adapted infrastructure and materials for students with disabilities, (e) basic drinking water, (f) single-sex basic sanitation facilities, and (g) basic handwashing facilities (as per the WASH indicator definitions)

4.b By 2020, substantially expand globally the number of scholarships available to developing countries, in particular least developed countries, small island developing States and African countries, for enrolment in higher education, including vocational training and information and communications technology, technical, engineering, and scientific programs, in developed countries and other developing countries

Increased amount of scholarship → improved school attendance → increased employment opportunity and increased income → improved care and feeding practices, food security, and household environments → improved diet and reduced disease → reduced undernutrition for themselves and offspring
a. Volume of official development assistance flows for scholarships by sector and type of study

4.c By 2030, substantially increase the supply of qualified teachers, including through international cooperation for teacher training in developing countries, especially least developed countries and small island developing states

Improved quality of workforce → improved education quality → improved knowledge and skill attainment → increased employment opportunity and increased income → improved care and feeding practices, food security, and household environments → improved diet and reduced disease → reduced undernutrition for themselves and offspring

a. Proportion of teachers in: (a) preprimary, (b) primary, (c) lower secondary, and (d) upper secondary education who have received at least the minimum organized teacher training (e.g., pedagogical training) preservice or in-service required for teaching at the relevant level in a given country
Goal 5: Achieve equality and empower all women and girls
5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere

Decreased discrimination → improved social context for women's empowerment → increased employment opportunity for women and increased income → improved household environment, access to health services and food security → improved dietary intake and reduced disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Whether or not legal frameworks are in place to promote, enforce, and monitor equality and nondiscrimination on the basis of sex
5.2 Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation

Reduced violence → improved women's empowerment and household stability → improved food security and health conditions → improved diet and reduced risks for diseases → reduced undernutrition for themselves and their children

a. Proportion of ever-partnered women and girls aged 15 years and older subjected to physical, sexual, or psychological violence by a current or former intimate partner in the previous 12 months by form of violence and by age
b. Proportion of women and girls aged 15 years and older subjected to sexual violence by persons other than an intimate partner in the previous 12 months by age and place of occurrence
5.3 Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early, and forced marriage, and female genital mutilation

Reduced child and early marriage → reduced adolescence pregnancy rate → more nutrition needs met during adolescence and better health condition → reduced risks for disease and complications when giving birth → reduced undernutrition for themselves and reduced likelihood of giving birth to newborns who are small for gestational age
a. Proportion of women aged 20–24 years who were married or in a union before age 15 and before age 18
b. Proportion of girls and women aged 15–49 years who have undergone female genital mutilation/cutting by age

5.6 Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Program of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences
Fewer unplanned birth → more adequate care given to newborns and improvements in prenatal care → reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of women aged 15–49 who make their own informed decisions regarding sexual relations, contraceptive use and reproductive health care
b. Number of countries with laws and regulations that guarantee women aged 15–49 access to sexual and reproductive care, information, and education

5.a Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance, and natural resources, in accordance with national laws

Improved political and economic context for women → equal rights to various resources → increased social, physical, and financial capital for women → improved household environment, access to health services, and food security → improved dietary intake and reduced disease → reduced undernutrition for themselves and their children

a. (a) Proportion of total agricultural population with ownership or secure rights over agricultural land by sex; and (b) share of women among owners or rights-bearers of agricultural land by type of tenure
b. Proportion of countries where the legal framework (including customary law) guarantees women's equal rights to land ownership and/or control
5.c Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels
a. Proportion of countries with systems to track and make public allocations for gender equality and women's empowerment
Goal 6: Ensure availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation for all
6.1 By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all
Improved access to clean water and sanitation services for all → improved household environment, care, and feeding practices → reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of population using safely managed drinking water services

6.2 By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations
a. Proportion of population using safely managed sanitation services, including a hand-washing facility with soap and water

6.a By 2030, expand international cooperation and capacity-building support to developing countries in water- and sanitation-related activities and programs, including water harvesting, desalination, water efficiency, wastewater treatment, recycling, and reuse technologies

Increased cooperation → improved water- and sanitation-related infrastructure development → increased access to clean water and sanitation services → improved household environment, care, and feeding practices → reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Amount of water- and sanitation-related official development assistance that is part of a government-coordinated spending plan
Goal 8: promote sustained, inclusive, and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment and decent work for all
8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value
Increased employment opportunities → increased financial and physical capital → better access to resources → improved dietary intake and reduced disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Average hourly earnings of female and male employees by occupation, age, and persons with disabilities
b. Unemployment rate by sex, age, and persons with disabilities

8.7 Take immediate and effective measures to eradicate forced labor, end modern slavery, and human trafficking and secure the prohibition and elimination of the worst forms of child labor, including recruitment and use of child soldiers, and by 2025 end child labor in all its forms

Reduced child labor → improved health conditions and increased time to access health services → reduced risk for diseases → reduced undernutrition
Reduced labor → increased access to and time for education → increased employment and income → increased food security, household environments, and access to health services → improved diet and reduced risk for diseases → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion and number of children aged 5–17 years engaged in child labor by sex and age
8.b By 2020, develop and operationalize a global strategy for youth employment and implement the Global Jobs Pact of the International Labor Organization

Improved government funding in youth employment programs → increased physical and financial capital → improved food security, household environment, and access to health services → improved dietary intake and reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Total government spending in social protection and employment programs as a proportion of the national budgets and GDP
Goal 10: reduce inequality within and among countries
10.1 By 2030, progressively achieve and sustain income growth of the bottom 40% of the population at a rate higher than the national average

Increased income → increased food security and access to health services, improved care, and feeding practices and household environments → improved diet and reduced risk for diseases → reduced undernutrition
a. Growth rates of household expenditure or income per capita among the bottom 40% of the population and the total population
10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic, and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion, or economic or other status

Improved social, economic, and political context → increased financial, social, and physical capital → improved food security, care, and feeding practices and household environments → improved dietary intake and reduced disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of people living below 50% of median income by age, sex, and persons with disabilities

10.3 Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies, and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies, and action in this regard

a. Proportion of the population reporting having personally felt discriminated against or harassed within the previous 12 months on the basis of a ground of discrimination prohibited under international human rights law
Goal 11: make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable
11.1 By 2030, ensure access for all to adequate, safe, and affordable housing and basic services and upgrade slums
Improved housing → improved household environments and care and feeding practices → reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of urban population living in slums, informal settlements or inadequate housing

11.2 By 2030, provide access to safe, affordable, accessible, and sustainable transport systems for all, improving road safety, notably by expanding public transport, with special attention to the needs of those in vulnerable situations, women, children, persons with disabilities, and older persons

Improved access to public transportation → improved food and health services facilities accessibility → improved diet and reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
Improved access to public transportation → improved market access → increased financial and physical capitals → increased access to resources → improved diet and reduced risks for disease → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of population that has convenient access to public transport, disaggregated by sex, age, and persons with disabilities
Goal 12: Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns
12.3 By 2030, halve per capita global food waste at the retail and consumer levels and reduce food losses along production and supply chains, including postharvest losses

Reduced food loss → increased food security availability and affordability for all → more adequate dietary intake → reduced undernutrition
Reduced resources waste related to food production, processing, and distribution → improved environmental footprint → increased likelihood for long-term food security and sustainable production → more adequate dietary intake for all → reduced undernutrition
Goal 13. Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts
13.1 Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries
Increased capacity against hazards and natural disasters → increased long-term food security for all → improved diet quantity and quality → reduced undernutrition
a. Number of countries with national and local disaster risk reduction strategies
b. Number of deaths, missing persons, and persons affected by disaster per 100,000 people
Goal 14. Conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas, and marine resources for sustainable development

14.4 By 2020, effectively regulate harvesting and end overfishing, illegal, unreported, and unregulated fishing and destructive fishing practices and implement science-based management plans, in order to restore fish stocks in the shortest time feasible, at least to levels that can produce maximum sustainable yield as determined by their biological characteristics

Sustainable fishing → adequate supply of fish and seafood → increased availability and affordability → improved diet quality → reduced undernutrition
Sustainable fishing → improved environmental footprint → increased likelihood for long-term food security and sustainable production → more adequate dietary intake for all → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of fish stocks within biologically sustainable levels
Goal 15. Protect, restore, and promote sustainable use of terrestrial ecosystems, sustainably manage forests, combat desertification, and halt and reverse land degradation and halt biodiversity loss
15.3 By 2030, combat desertification, restore degraded land and soil, including land affected by desertification, drought and floods, and strive to achieve a land degradation-neutral world
Improved soil quality → increased crops quality/yields and stable crop production → increased likelihood for long-term food security → more adequate dietary intake for all → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of land that is degraded over total land area
Goal 17. Strengthen the means of implementation and revitalize the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development

17.8 Fully operationalize the technology bank and science, technology and innovation capacity-building mechanism for least developed countries by 2017 and enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology

Increased access to information technology → continuously improving human capital → increased employment opportunity and higher income → increased access to different resources → improved diets and reduced risks for diseases → reduced undernutrition
a. Proportion of individuals using the Internet
17.13 Enhance global macroeconomic stability, including through policy coordination and policy coherence

Increased economic and political coherence → improved social, economic, and political context and stability → increased financial, human, physical, and social capital for all → increased access to different resources → improved diet and reduced risk for diseases → reduced undernutrition
17.14 Enhance policy coherence for sustainable development
a. Number of countries with mechanisms in place to enhance policy coherence of sustainable development

17.16 Enhance the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development, complemented by multistakeholder partnerships that mobilize and share knowledge, expertise, technology, and financial resources, to support the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals in all countries, in particular developing countries

Increased global partnership → improved social, economic, and political context → increased financial, human, physical, and social capital for all → increased access to different resources → improved diet and reduced risk for diseases → reduced undernutrition
a. Number of countries reporting progress in multistakeholder development effectiveness monitoring frameworks that support the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals

17.18 By 2020, enhance capacity-building support to developing countries, including for least developed countries and small island developing states, to increase significantly the availability of high-quality, timely, and reliable data disaggregated by income, gender, age, race, ethnicity, migratory status, disability, geographic location, and other characteristics relevant in national contexts

Improved data management and monitoring → improved accountability → improved social and economic context → increased access to different resources for all → improved diet and reduced risks for diseases → reduced undernutrition

a. Proportion of sustainable development indicators produced at the national level with full disaggregation when relevant to the target, in accordance with the Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics
b. Number of countries that have national statistical legislation that complies with the Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: An Overview of Data Gaps for Each Target Across the Different Regions

row.entry: Target 1.1 proportion of population below the international poverty line
Target 1.3 Proportion of unemployed population covered by social protection floors/systems
Target 1.a Proportion of resources allocated directly to poverty reduction programs
Target 1.a Proportion of government expenditure on health, education, and social protection
Target 2.1 prevalence of moderate or severe food insecurity
Target 2.a Agricultural orientation index for government expenditures
Target 3.3 New HIV infection; malaria incidence; Number of people requiring interventions against neglected tropical diseases
Target 3.3 Tuberculosis and hepatitis B incidence
Target 3.7 Percentage of women who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods; Adolescents age 15–19 years fertility rate
Target 3.7 Adolescents age 10–14 years fertility rate
Target 4.2 Proportion of children aged 36–59 months of age who are developmentally on track
Target 4.2 Percentage of children enrolled in organized learning (preprimary education)
Target 4.4 Proportion of individuals using the internet (%)
Target 4.4 Proportion of individuals having a computer or a mobile phone
Target 5.3 Proportion of women married before age 15 or age 18
Target 8.5 Unemployment rate by age group
Target 8.7 proportion of children age 5–14 years engaged in child labor
Target 8.7 Proportion of children age 15–17 years engaged in child labor
Target 13.1 Number of countries with national and local disaster risk reduction strategies
Target 13.1 Average death rate due to natural disasters

ce:legend.ce:simple-para: Data are for two of Target 3.7 indicator: women's need for family planning satisfied with modern methods; adolescents age 15–19 years fertility rate.

ce:sections.ce:para: This case study illustrates the trickle-down effects of the basic causes of malnutrition on underlying and immediate causes in Palestine. The use of UNICEF's framework on the causes of malnutrition aids in providing a comprehensive understanding of the factors affiliated with and continuously perpetuate the prevalence rates of the multiple burdens of malnutrition present in Palestine.

Overall, 7.4% of Palestinian children under the age of 5 are stunted and face chronic malnutrition and 1.2% are wasted (WFP, 2016). At the same time, 8% of children under five are overweight (WFP, 2016). There is also evidence of the double burden of stunting and overweight and obesity among Palestinian children (Ghattas et al., 2017; Massad et al., 2012). High rates of micronutrient deficiencies, particularly anemia, also exist (WHO, 2012). Nearly half of young children 12–15 months suffer from anemia (PCBS, 2017). These multiple burdens of malnutrition have both immediate and long-term impacts on the health and wellbeing of children living in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip (Turner et al., 2016).

Basic causes: Basic causes of malnutrition in Palestine include political instability, marginalization, and low employment, among others. Political marginalization indirectly affects the health of the people living in those communities, including fostering circumstances that lead to malnutrition in children and adults. Marginalization is a process in which individuals are blocked from enjoying the rights of full citizenship and social privileges that include the rights to basic economic and social welfare as well as participation in the society, consisting of work opportunities, education, and fulfillment of basic needs in terms of access to medical aid and food supplies (Giacaman, 2001). Since the beginning of the occupation in 1948, the Palestinians have faced numerous physical and mental health difficulties due to marginalization (Devi, 2004). The Israeli government has placed various restrictions that have impeded on the quality of life of the Palestinian people (Devi, 2004). Checkpoints, construction of the Israeli wall, and continued growth of Israeli settlements are only a few of the physical barriers that encourage the disfranchisement of Palestinians (Devi, 2004). Figurative forms of marginalization manifest themselves in manners such as restrictive movement, primarily as a result of the physical barriers, limiting employment possibilities and access to healthcare facilities and provisions, and poor living conditions (UN, 2010). With 25.8% of the population living below the poverty line (38.8% in Gaza, 17.8% in the West Bank) and high unemployment rates (40% in Gaza, 20% in the West Bank), obtaining basic resources is extremely difficult (Turner et al., 2016).

All of these various restrictions have severely encroached on the nutritional statuses of the Palestinians, particularly the children. In addition to the burden of nutrition attributed to these basic causes, children are highly susceptible mental health issues associated with traumatic events, and enduring social problems brought by the conflict (Tsigga and Grammatikopoulou, 2012). Lack of employment and inadequate financial capacity create barriers to food access (Basak, 2012). These basic causes of malnutrition subsequently influence the underlying and immediate causes of malnutrition.

Underlying causes: Underlying causes of malnutrition include food insecurity, both in the Gaza Strip and West Bank, inaccessibility to health services (primarily through physical barriers due to checkpoints), and water and environmental sanitation issues (UN-OCHA, 2016). As of January 2018, 1.6 million people total in Palestine were food insecure and in need of food assistance—39% in Gaza and 13% in the West Bank (WFP, 2018). Households spend more than 50% of their monthly income on food, and high food prices make it difficult for families to purchase nutritious foods (Kampschoer, 2014). A significant proportion of the population relies on food aid. In January 2018, the World Food Program assisted 263,570 beneficiaries with food aid (WFP, 2018). However, challenges in reaching all of those in need remain due to funding limitations. At the same time, food aid solely eases immediate food needs rather than providing sustainable access (WFP, 2018). Food production is limited as a result of natural conditions, consistent conflict causing severe damage to land resources, and Israeli land-use controls (Turner et al., 2016). In addition to barriers to accessing food, there are challenges in accessing safe water. Fifty-five percent of the Gaza Strip faces severe energy needs and only 5% of the piped water is potable (UN-OCHA, 2016).

Immediate causes: The immediate causes can be seen in the interplay between inadequate dietary intake and illness. Children face acute respiratory infections as well as occurrences of diarrhea due to poor environmental health and hygiene condition (Abu Mourad et al., 2008). Illness and infections then affect the body's ability to absorb the nutrients consumed through the diet (Abu Mourad et al., 2008). The nutrient-rich diets needed to maintain proper growth are lacking in marginalized communities, thus hindering overall growth and development of children and contributing to the multiple burdens of malnutrition.

The success of reducing the multiple burdens of malnutrition in Palestine is contingent upon a comprehensive understanding of the multitude of factors that perpetuate its existence and the need to address all three types of causes simultaneously. This could be achieved through addressing the SDGs. Confronting the roots of these causes challenges the systems in place that hinder the achievement of SDGs 1, 2, 6, 7, 8, 11, and 16. Tackling the underlying and immediate causes directly impacts goals 2 (no hunger), 6 (clean water and sanitation), and 11 (sustainable cities and communities). Meanwhile, confronting basic causes impacts goals 1 (no poverty), 7 (affordable and clean energy), 8 (decent work and economic growth), and 16 (peace, justice, and strong institutions). It is crucial that prioritization of needs of the Palestinian people be at the forefront of all nutrition-related interventions.

head.ce:label: Chapter Nine
head.ce:title: The Role of the Sustainable Development Goals to Reduce the Global Burden of Malnutrition

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Rutgers School of Public Health, Piscataway Township, NJ, United States
Institute of Human Nutrition, Columbia University, New York, NY, United States
Johns Hopkins Berman Institute of Bioethics, Baltimore, MD, United States

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Johns Hopkins Berman Institute of Bioethics

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: UNICEF's conceptual framework outlines the basic, underlying, and immediate causes of malnutrition and provides an overview of both the direct and indirect pathways to reduce malnutrition and improve health outcomes. Sustainable development goal (SDG) 2 aims to “end hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture”, which has the potential to directly influence nutrition outcomes. However, many of the other SDGs have the potential to improve nutrition outcomes through more indirect pathways. Using the UNICEF conceptual framework to guide our analysis, we examined the ways in which different SDGs could influence nutrition and health outcomes, and the pathways by which this could occur. However, large data gaps exist making it difficult to accurately assess the current state of SDGs in many countries and regions. In order to increase accountability for the SDGs, the existing gaps in data collection must be addressed. This will enable countries to examine both the indirect and the direct pathways to improving nutrition outcomes globally.

ce:section.ce:para: Reducing malnutrition is a challenge that persists for many countries around the world. Malnutrition manifests itself in various forms, with approximately 88% of countries facing multiple burdens such as childhood stunting, anemia, and overweight that significantly impact the health status and quality of life of millions of people worldwide (Development Initiatives, 2017). Progress has been made to address these burdens, especially in reducing undernutrition, but significant challenges remain. The prevalence of maternal and child undernutrition remains high in many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) (Black et al., 2008; Development Initiatives, 2017). There are currently 815 million people who are hungry, 150.8 million children under five who are stunted, and approximately 50.5 million who are wasted, as well as billions of people with micronutrient deficiencies globally (UNICEF, WHO, and World Bank Group, 2018). Simultaneously, the prevalence of overweight/obesity and diet-related noncommunicable diseases (NCDs) continues to increase both in high-income countries as well as in LMICs with a total of 2 billion adults and 41 million children currently overweight or obese (Development Initiatives, 2017).

UNICEF's conceptual framework on the causes of malnutrition, originally developed in 1991 and since modified to incorporate new information and evidence, recognizes the multifactorial determinants of maternal and child nutrition, as well as their consequences and impacts. The framework classifies the causes of malnutrition into three categories: basic, immediate, and underlying (Fig. 1 ). The ultimate goal of delineating these causes is to inform the comprehensive assessment and analysis of the drivers of nutrition-related problems and thus, identify ways to address them. Basic causes include systemic challenges, such as political, social, cultural, and economic issues that lead to an unequal distribution of human, institutional, and financial capital as well as other significant resources (Reinhardt and Fanzo, 2014). Underlying causes include household food security, care and feeding practices, access to quality health services, and a clean environment. Both the basic and underlying causes can affect the immediate causes of undernutrition, which include inadequate dietary intake and/or increased disease frequency and severity. In turn, malnutrition can have short- and long-term consequences, including increasing the risk of overweight and obesity and diet-related NCD, that span generations (Reinhardt and Fanzo, 2014). In order to tackle the global burden of malnutrition, the basic, underlying, and immediate causes all need to be addressed. Given the complexity of trying to understand the multitude of factors that cause malnutrition, applying a framework that guides the identification of basic, underlying, and immediate causes of malnutrition to specific country contexts can help to identify priority areas for action. For this reason, among others, the UNICEF framework continues to be widely used even 30 years since its initial development.

Over the past few decades, there has been an increased global effort to address the burden of malnutrition. The United Nations (UN), in particular, has taken up initiatives to work toward more successful achievement of development agendas, including the millennium development goals (MDGs) established in 2000 followed by the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in 2015. These development agendas, undertaken by the international communities, aim to work toward all aspects affiliated with overall equitable prosperity through the eradication of all forms of poverty and achievement of universal peace (ECOSOC, 2016). In addition to the MDGs and SDGs, which include targets related to malnutrition, the UN Decade of Action on Nutrition calls for broader improvements in nutrition globally, as described in more detail below.

The MDGs provided concrete and measurable goals, targets, and time-bound indicators to fight poverty and undernutrition from 2000 to 2015. By 2015, significant progress had been made toward achieving the MDGs (UN, 2010, 2015a, b), but it was uneven across countries and regions, and large gaps separated the poorest and richest households, as well as rural and urban areas (Armah, 2015; Fehling et al., 2013). Moreover, key indicators related to malnutrition were left off of the MDG agenda, including stunting (i.e., chronic undernutrition) and overweight/obesity.

In September 2015, the SDGs superseded the MDGs. The SDGs differ from the MDGs in their breadth and scope: the SDGs aim to enhance global equity, environmental sustainability, and partnership (ECOSOC, 2016; Kumar et al., 2016). There are 17 goals and 169 associated targets for sustainable growth and equal resource distribution for all people that make up the SDGs (Kumar et al., 2016). SDG 2 aims to “end hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture.” Whereas the MDGs focused exclusively on LMICs, all countries are expected to work toward achieving the SDGs (Kumar et al., 2016). Each of these goals, and their corresponding targets, has associated indicators in order to track progress toward the successful achievement of the 2030 agenda. They span a wide range of topics including income equality, gender and sex, health, educational and environmental justice, and other economic and social issues. Although covering a plethora of development and equity issues, the indicators are not all-encompassing and important development issues were still left out of the targets. For example, adult obesity is not included in the indicators (ECOSOC, 2016) despite its large global burden (Ng et al., 2014).

To further address malnutrition, the UN's Decade of Action on Nutrition (2016–25) promotes the global nutrition agenda and supports the objectives set forth by the SDGs (FAO, 2016). The Decade is a country-driven initiative that engages all nutrition stakeholders in developing specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART) commitments by 2025. This global, collective effort calls for action across six pillars of nutrition: sustainable food systems for healthy diets; health systems providing universal coverage of essential nutrition actions; social protection and nutrition education; trade and investment for improved nutrition; enabling food and breastfeeding environments; and nutrition governance and accountability (FAO, 2016).

The focus of this chapter is on the role of the SDGs to improve nutrition outcomes through both direct and the indirect pathways. Although SDG 2 is the only goal specifically focused on addressing malnutrition, it is likely that many of the other SDGs could influence malnutrition through their effects on the underlying and basic causes of malnutrition. Thus, the aim of this chapter is to: (1) examine how the different SDGs may affect the basic, underlying, and immediate causes of maternal and child malnutrition and (2) use existing data to assess the progress countries have made on these SDGs in order to identify where greater attention is needed to tackle malnutrition.

For the purpose of this chapter and for further understanding how SDGs can influence nutrition, they have been aligned with the UNICEF's Framework of the basic, underlying, and immediate causes in addition to the short- and long-term consequences of undernutrition. Fig. 2 demonstrates the ways in which various SDGs influence the basic, underlying, and immediate causes of maternal and child undernutrition based on the framework. This approach has been conducted to demonstrate the multiple pathways by which the SDGs could help to address the burdens of malnutrition. Overweight/obesity and NCDs are only included in the UNICEF framework as long-term consequences; however, they will be considered as one of the forms of malnutrition in this section. Overall, three SDGs (SDGs 2, 3, and 6) have been identified as having direct effects on malnutrition by influencing the immediate and underlying causes of undernutrition. SDGs 14 and 15 also influence the underlying causes of malnutrition by affecting food security, while 11 other SDGs (SDGs 1, 4, 5, 8, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, and 17) have the potential to indirectly affect malnutrition by addressing basic causes. We describe these in further detail below. Case Study 1 provides an overview of the basic, underlying, and immediate causes of malnutrition in Palestine.

SDG 2, which pertains to working toward achieving sustainable solutions aimed at improving household food security, feeding practices, and access to quality nutritious food items, has the potential to ensure adequate dietary intake and reduce the risk for undernutrition. SDG 3 may improve access to care and lead to reductions in disease prevalence and severity, and mortality rate for the current generation, consequently, leading to reductions in malnutrition risks for the next generation as well. These risks include immediate negative outcomes such as mortality, morbidity, and disability and long-term outcomes such as stunting, reduced cognitive development, neurological problems, and increased likelihoods of obesity and NCDs (Black et al., 2013; Martorell and Zongrone, 2012). SDG 6 aims to improve access to clean water and sanitation, directly improving the household environment which can reduce infections and the prevalence of maternal and child malnutrition. SDGs 14 and 15 cover both environmental justice and the feedback loop in the relationship between humans and earth in regards to production and consumption, and consequent diminishing availability and quality of food. Thus, they impact not only the underlying causes through its effects on household food security but also on basic causes as life below water and life on land both influence and are influenced by sociocultural, economic, and political contexts.

Increasing the various sources of capital including financial, human, physical, and social, as intended by goals 1 and 4 ultimately leads to overall improved household access to an adequate quantity and quality of resources, such as land, education, employment, income, and technology. Attaining these resources creates a chain effect that can potentially lead to decreased prevalence of undernutrition. SDGs 5, 8, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, and 17 can improve and stabilize the sociocultural, economic, environmental, and political contexts. These changes are essential to ensuring that resources are used efficiently and distributed equitably for the achievement of national development and the eradication of malnutrition. Although synergies and convergences exist among the goals, there are various instances in which there may be trade-offs in achieving one goal at the behest of another.

The Inter-Agency and Expert Group on Sustainable Development Goals (IAEG-SG), established in 2015 in collaboration with the Statistical Commission, have identified a total of 229 indicators for most, but not all, of the SDGs (ECOSOC, 2016). Having indicators for all of the SDGs, and their targets, is critical in order to track progress as part of the 2030 agenda. The IAEG-SDG indicator global framework aims to provide a set of indicators, for both specific population groups and geographical areas, which can be used in all countries and allows for continual assessment and monitoring of the goals and targets of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development within each region (ECOSOC, 2016). Table 1 describes the specific pathways by which each of the identified SDGs may influence maternal and child malnutrition, as well as the indicators used to measure these SDGS. The tier classification in the table, as defined by the IAEG, categorizes each indicator based on its clarity, methodology, and establishment of international standards (UN, 2016). Indicators considered to be Tier I are those that are conceptually clear, have internationally established standards, and data pertaining to affiliated targets are regularly produced by countries (UN, 2016). Twenty-six of the indicators were considered Tier III, which indicates that no internationally established methodology or standards are yet available for those indicators, but are being developed/tested (UN, 2016).

The purpose of assessing the SDGs and associated targets through the indicators developed by IAEG is to identify potential pathways for improvements in malnutrition and evaluate the progress that is necessary for countries to address and meet the SDGs by 2030. A compilation of data obtained by searching surveys, reports, and several different databases provides information on the current status of indicators within the nine respective regions, as determined by the Global Nutrition Report: sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), Northern Africa, South Asia, South East Asia, Eastern Asia, Western and Central Asia, Latin America and Caribbean, Europe and Northern America, and Oceania (Global Nutrition Report, 2017). Sources include but were not limited to: World Bank (WB), International Labor Organization (ILO), Global Nutrition Report, Countdown to 2015, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (MNCH), International Telegraph Union (ITU), United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), and UN Women.

Data availability and gaps were examined for each indicator and region. Of the selected indicators, the countries in a particular region that had data available were calculated as a percentage, based on the number of total countries divided by the number of countries within the region. To avoid redundancy, indicators were grouped and targets that had similar data availability and/or were compiled from the same source were combined. Data for genital mutilation/cutting and for official development assistance were not included, as they only pertained to a limited number of countries. After compiling the data, the mean (average), minimum value, and maximum value for each of the selected indicators were examined for each respective region.

Eighty-three indicators were included in the analysis with a few exceptions due to difficulty in calculating means, and minimum and maximum values for some variables given the way that the data were reported. More specifically, data were reported as <5% for Target 2.1, <0.1 for two indicators for Target 3.3, and in national currency for Target 2.b, and only for a limited number of countries, which made intercountry comparison difficult. Data for Targets 4.a and 4.c were only available for countries in Africa, and data for Target 5.3 were only applicable to countries in Africa and a few countries in Asia. Data for Target 6.a were generally recorded by the provider rather than by the receiver and thus limited to a few countries. Lastly, data were reported as “yes” or “no” for Target 13.1, and not as numerical values.

Several gaps exist within the data availability across different countries and/or across goals and targets as a result of differences in systematic collection of necessary information. Table 2 provides an overview of the data gaps for the different goals and targets associated with the basic, underlying, and immediate causes of malnutrition. The percentages indicate the proportion of countries within each of the nine regions with data available for each of the targets, thus shedding light on the extent of the existing gaps in data availability globally, and the differences among regions. While countries in Africa and South Asia, have more data available, locations in regions of Oceania, Europe, and North America do not have as much information available or are updated less frequently. Indicators covered under the MDGs, such as data for components of SDG 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8, were more likely to have data available, while some of the newly developed indicators for the SDGs lacked systematic data collection methods, including an internationally agreed upon standard or reporting methodology. Data were lacking for SDGs 11, 12, 13, and 17 and their given subtargets. These SDGs relate to a country's infrastructure and environment (i.e., basic causes of malnutrition), which are generally difficult to quantify and measure. There were also no data available for SDGs 14 and 15 which pertain to life in the water and on the land, respectively. Moreover, for many countries there was also a limited range of data that had been disaggregated by age, gender, region (urban or rural), and able-bodied status.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The Current State of SDG Indicators Across Countries and Regions
Maternal and Child Malnutrition: Short- and Long-Term Consequences
ce:section.ce:para: The prevalence of short- and long-term consequences of malnutrition can be observed with different levels of variability. For the short-term consequences of maternal and child malnutrition (e.g., mortality), variability is quite high among and within regions. However, the long-term consequences of undernutrition, namely mortality attributed to NCDs among adults aged 30–70, is less variable, ranging from 16.4% in Latin America and the Caribbean to 21.2% in Western and Central Asia.

Malnutrition in children under five was variable depending on region and type of malnutrition. Table 3 depicts the average prevalence of stunting, wasting, and overweight in children under five for each region. The range in the mean prevalence of stunting was wide (7.4%–31.6%), with the highest prevalence in SSA and the lowest in Europe and North America. In SSA, the country with the highest prevalence of stunting was Burundi and the lowest was Seycehelle. In Europe and North America, the highest prevalence of stunting was Albania and the lowest was Germany. While a total of 46 countries were examined in the sub-Saharan African region, information on only nine countries was obtained for Europe and North America, which has implication for the interpretation of the data included in the table. The range in the prevalence of wasting was even wider (5.2%–40%), with South Asia having the highest prevalence and Europe and North America the least. Similarly, data in 45 countries in the sub-Saharan African region were collected, in which South Sudan had the highest prevalence of wasting and Swaziland the lowest, while only nine countries were examined in Europe and North America, with Albania having the highest prevalence and the United States, the lowest. These vast differences across regions may be a result of a vast plethora of factors including but not limited to issues pertaining to development including lack of resources for populations or simply a lack of appropriate data collection mechanisms to obtain accurate information. Regions with higher levels of development, and countries classified as high income, have the lowest prevalence of the indicators of undernutrition. On the other hand, the range in the prevalence of overweight among children under five (3.8%–13.1%) is much smaller across different regions, regardless of the stage of development. The highest prevalence of overweight in children under five is in Europe, North America, and North Africa: Libya has the highest prevalence (22.4%) and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea has the lowest (~0%). In all regions but South Asia, at least one country has a prevalence of overweight in children under five that exceeds 10%. Thus, child overweight affects nearly all countries and regions worldwide. Maternal malnutrition is not measured as it does not have an affiliated target included within the SDGs. It is crucial, however, that the nutritional status of mothers be taken into account as it is highly indicative of the nutritional statuses of not only their children but also their entire households as well as future offspring (UNICEF, 2009).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Indicators of Underlying Causes of Child and Maternal Malnutrition
ce:section.ce:para: For indicators related to the underlying causes of malnutrition, there is a wider variability in the prevalence between more economically stable regions, such as East Asia, and Europe and North America, and less affluent ones, especially SSA (Table 4 ). Indicators relating to healthcare services, safe drinking water, and food insecurity showed that conditions are better for populations in Europe and North America, and East Asia (and Oceania for food insecurity) than in SSA, where food insecurity is the highest.

Although the overall trends revealed that underlying causes of malnutrition are more prevalent in less developed regions, the analysis also highlighted important nuances. In regions where food insecurity is highly prevalent, the range of its prevalence is large, indicating a significant discrepancy in food security within the same region. Among healthcare indicators, there is less variability among regions for family planning. Even regions that include mainly high-income countries only satisfied the family planning needs of approximately half of women. The proportion of the population using safe drinking water is high among most regions: although SSA has the lowest average, it is still relatively high at 73%. It is also notable that within every region there are countries reaching 98%–100% of the population using safe drinking water.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Indicators of Basic Causes of Maternal and Child Undernutrition
ce:section.ce:para: The examination of SDG indicators for targets that affect malnutrition through basic causes show that conditions are better in more affluent regions, as is the case with underlying causes of malnutrition. Table 4 demonstrates the averages for the indicators of the SDGs that address basic causes of malnutrition for each region, as well as corresponding countries with the highest and lowest values for those indicators. SSA has the highest proportion of the population below the international poverty line with Democratic Republic of Congo having the greatest proportion and Mauritius having the least. Information on poverty levels in the regions of Northern Africa, Eastern Asia, and Oceania were either missing and/or limited. Data were also missing for the regions of Eastern Asia and Oceania for the indicators relating to the proportion of male and female children age 5–14 years engaged in child labor and female child labor. Less developed regions have a larger proportion of people living below the international poverty line, lower literacy and employment rates, and less government expenditure on social protection. These regions also experience a higher prevalence of child labor and violence against women, influential elements that impact individual and community levels of nutrition due to the interactions that exist between gender and health (FAO, 2012). Gender-based violence, particularly aimed at women, impacts nutrition by diminishing physical access to resources, harming women and girls in their productive and reproductive years leading to poor pregnancy outcomes and increased levels of child mortality and morbidity, all of which hinders their capacities to be household earners and caregivers, thus consequently reinforcing the cycles of poverty.

For indicators related to government expenditures, violence against women, and informal housing, wealthier regions do not uniformly outperform less affluent ones. Though government expenditure on social protection is the lowest in the world's poorest regions, the reverse is true for education spending: education expenditures are the highest in South East Asia (18.7%) and the lowest in Europe and North America (10.3%). The prevalence of violence against women varies regionally depending on the perpetrator: violence perpetrated by a current or former partner against women and girls 15 years and older is high in SSA (27.3%) and South Asia (23.8%), but violence perpetrated by someone other than one's partner is the highest in Europe and North America (5.7%) and Oceania (18%). The proportion of households living in informal settlements is high in several regions, such as SSA (59.3%) and South Sudan (96%), but it is notable that in all regions with data, there are some countries with very high levels of informal settlements (South Sudan—96%, Sudan—92%, Afghanistan—63%, Cambodia—55%, Mongolia—43%, Yemen—61%, and Haiti—74%).

The SDGs usher in a new era by virtue of their comprehensive, multisectoral focus, which is essential for the widespread improvement of nutrition. They call for the collection of data on a wide range of indicators in all countries around the world, two features which distinguish the SDGs from the MDGs. The breadth of the SDGs also may help direct policy attention to problems that hinder sustainable development in LMICs and promote greater awareness of issues shared by different countries and regions, regardless of their geography or wealth. Shared knowledge on best practices for addressing the dietary risk factors of NCDs, a growing problem around the world, could be one such positive outcome.

The comprehensiveness of the SDGs has the potential to engender more sustainability for the goals that are achieved. Progress made in one SDG area has the potential to buttress other SDGs, a cobenefit that is especially relevant for the basic and underlying causes of malnutrition. However, in order to ensure this sustainability, increased data collection and greater accountability are needed. The progress achieved by the SDGs will likely have lasting effects that improve the development outcomes of future generations. Investments in education and social protection, two sectors that have close linkages with nutrition outcomes, can promote intergenerational changes in nutritional status and overall health (FAO, 2015).

The causes of malnutrition must also be addressed using multifaceted and sustainable approaches within each country. For many countries, it is likely that the most basic causes of malnutrition will have to be addressed before the burden of malnutrition can be substantially reduced. This is particularly true for countries that have ongoing conflict. Mitigating the political, economic, and social causes of malnutrition will increase the likelihood of sustained good nutrition and improve the resilience of communities to shocks.

In every region of the world, there is at least one country with over 40% of the population living in informal housing. Lack of stable housing coincides with limited access to clean water and sanitation, which can greatly affect nutrition. In countries with very high proportions of the population living in informal housing, addressing this basic cause of malnutrition could lead to significant improvements in the burden of malnutrition. As seen in Palestine, in order to encourage sustainable solutions, solely providing food through aid without conflict resolution is ineffective. Interventions and policies must be contextualized, prioritize the needs of the population, and ensure that basic, underlying, and immediate causes of malnutrition are addressed in order to ensure sustainability.

Nutrition can improve around the world as countries make progress on their respective goals, even goals that are not nutrition specific. Making headway on goals that influence the basic or underlying causes of malnutrition can have tremendous positive effects on malnutrition overall. Education, family planning, violence against women, and housing stability are all sectors that can have significant effects on nutrition, in every and all regions around the world, regardless of development status. It is important to make note that global inequities that exist in all regions, hinder the ability to foster resilient systems including those related to food and nutrition. Even in the United States, one of the world's “richest, most powerful and technologically innovative countries…40 million people continue to live in poverty” (OHCHR, 2017). When there is political and social will to counter the causes of poverty that fall in line with basic causes of malnutrition, there is strong chance for elimination of poor nutrition (OHCHR, 2017). One of the ways to break the poverty cycle is by education (FAO, 2015). It is encouraging that government expenditure on education is high in some of the poorest regions of the world, where the least progress has been achieved on the SDGs.

The comprehensive, multisectoral focus of the SDGs has the potential to transcend the pitfalls of the MDGs, but concerns over data must be resolved in order to allow for better measurement of progress and increase accountability. There are large gaps in the data available to measure the SDGs, which must be addressed through a significant investment in data collection. This lack of data makes it far more difficult for countries to develop and meet their commitments, let alone to adhere to the UN's SMART guidelines or track progress over time. It reduces accountability of all stakeholders involved including the government as well as civil society and nongovernmental organizations. Disaggregated data are especially important for identifying inequities in progress and attaining the goals for different subsets of the population.

Making progress in attaining the SDGs will lead to substantial advancements in addressing the burden of malnutrition through both direct and indirect pathways. In order to achieve reductions in malnutrition, investment across multiple sectors will be needed. In many countries, it is likely that addressing the most basic causes of malnutrition will be necessary before reducing the burden of malnutrition will be possible. Every country will have a different path toward addressing the SDGs, and these approaches should be based on country context and prioritized based on the needs of the population. However, in order to ensure that measuring progress is possible, existing data gaps will need to be addressed and investment in surveillance systems required. With measurement comes accountability, and with accountability for commitments comes the real potential for reducing the burden of malnutrition.
